Amendment No. 100 provides for the amendment of the Credit Union Act 1997 as follows. Section 8 of the Bill specifies the intervention conditions to be fulfilled in relation to an authorised credit institution. These conditions must be fulfilled before the Central Bank can make a proposed transfer order or a proposed special management order. Condition C of the intervention conditions relates to the failure to comply with a regulatory requirement, for example a regulatory direction. Section 87 of the 1997 act sets out the power of the Central Bank to issue regulatory directions to credit unions in certain circumstances, for example where a credit union is unable to meet its obligations to its members or where it no longer possesses adequate capital resources. The amendment adds to the types of directions the Central Bank may issue to a credit union in such circumstances. The second part is a technical amendment that is required because of the amendment being made to section 129 of the 1997 Act. This amendment is required to ensure that, where a credit union transfers voluntarily on foot of a board resolution, the common bond of the transferee changes automatically to include that of the transferor. This ensures common membership criteria for the amalgamated entity.

Amendment No. 101 provides for the amendment of two other enactments, the Land and Conveyancing Law Reform Act 2009 and the Credit Institutions (Stabilisation) Act 2010. The amendments are in addition to the amendments already set out in the Bill. They can be considered in two broad categories, amendments that form part of the new steady-state SRR framework and amendments to the Credit Institutions (Stabilisation) Act 2010, which provides the legal framework for the restructuring of the banking sector as agreed under the EU and IMF programme.

The amendments to the 2009 Act are as follows. Item 1 is consequential to item 3, which inserts a new subsection 74(5) and provides that this subsection is also subject to that new subsection. Item 2 is consequential to item 3, which inserts a new subsection 74(5) and provides that this subsection is also subject to that new subsection.

Item 3 provides that the disposal of property by the Central Bank pursuant to an order under the Bill does not amount to a voluntary disposition or conveyance of property. This amendment is necessary so that any disposal of property under the Bill cannot be set aside by a subsequent purchaser of property which was transferred under the Bill by reason of it being a voluntary disposition of land made with the intention of defrauding the subsequent purchaser, or by reason of it by being a conveyance of property made with the intention of defrauding a creditor or other person.

Items 4 to 49 amend the Credit Institutions (Stabilisation) Act 2010 as follows. Item 4 amends the interpretation section to provide that the preservation of the financial position of a relevant institution is to be taken to include the need for it to comply with an order made or requirement imposed under the CIS Act or the capital adequacy regulations.

Item 5 amends section 4(g) by substituting “or” for “and” to reflect the wording in the credit institutions winding up directive, which uses “provide or restore” in the definition of reorganisation measures.
Item 6 adds a new section 5A which imposes an express requirement on the Minister and the Central Bank to have regard to the laws of the EU in performing their functions.

Item 7 amends section 7(1) to provide that a direction order does not have to be limited to a particular action but can extend to a series of actions that are together designed to achieve a particular objective.

Item 8 deletes section 9(6) of the CIS Act, which states: "The Court may give a direction, as it thinks appropriate, in relation to the publication of a direction order." The amended section 9 will provide for a more prescriptive and extensive process in relation to the publication of direction orders, which makes it no longer necessary to require the court to give directions. The Minister will be obliged to publish in two national newspapers and he or she may publish by an additional means in an additional place. In addition, where a relevant institution has its shares traded on a financial market, upon being served with the order by the Minister, it will be required to announce the existence of the order to a regulatory news service and to provide it with a copy of the order. The intention is to provide for the widest possible dissemination of the existence of the order among the people who might be affected by it.

Item 9 amends section 9(7) to provide clarity as to when a direction order has effect in particular scenarios. Direction orders can have immediate effect where this is so ordered by the court. Where the direction does not need to have immediate effect, it will take effect 14 days after the publication of the order. Provision is also made for where applications are made to set aside a direction order and in each case identified in the section, the effect of such an application on the effectiveness of the order is set out. In each case, the court will have the power to specify the date of effectiveness.

Item 10 inserts a new section 9A. Together with item 8, it will provide a more prescriptive and extensive publication regime for direction orders. Rather than leave it to the court's discretion, the Minister will be obliged to publish in two national newspapers and he may publish by an additional means in an additional place. Furthermore, where a relevant institution has its shares traded on a financial market, upon being served with the order by the Minister, it will be required to announce the existence of the order to a regulatory news service and to provide it with a copy of the order. The intention is to provide for the widest possible dissemination of the existence of the order among the people who might be affected by it. A regulatory news service transmits regulatory and non-regulatory information published by companies with securities - for example shares and bonds - listed on a stock exchange and organisations allowing them to comply with local market transparency legislation.

Item 11 amends section 11(1) to increase the time in which an application to set aside direction orders may be brought from five working days after the making of a direction order to 14 days after the publication of a direction order. The effect will be to give applicants more time to consider their position. The extension of the period in which set-aside can be sought is consequential to the decision to provide that orders can have immediate effect in order to balance competing rights.

Item 12 amends section 11(2) to provide clarity with regard to the Court's power to make directions as to matters arising during the currency of an application to set aside. Item 13 amends section 11(5) to provide clarity as to the effectiveness of a direction order where an application to set aside is unsuccessful.

Item 14 amends section 11 to provide that in an application to set aside a direction order, where the applicant is a member of the relevant institution, the court will be permitted to take into consideration when an applicant became a member, when he or she increased or decreased his or her shareholdings in the institution concerned, and the value of any shares acquired or disposed on the dates of acquisition or disposal.

This amendment is proposed in response to the Department's practical experience in applying for orders under the Credit Institutions Stabilisation, CIS, Act since its commencement in December 2010. It is based on the principle that the court should be permitted to take into account the behaviour of the applicant when considering a challenge. For example, a number of members who challenged the Irish Life & Permanent direction order acquired the majority of their shares following 31 March 2011 when it was clear the bank would be recapitalised and members' interests diluted.

Item 15 is a technical amendment to section 13(2) to correct an oversight in the CIS Act as enacted. Item 16 deletes section 14(6) of the CIS Act which states, "The Court may give a direction, as it thinks appropriate, in relation to the publication of a special management order."

Section 14 as amended will provide for a more prescriptive process for the publication of special management orders, which makes it no longer necessary to require the court to give directions. The Minister will be obliged to publish in two national newspapers and he or she may publish by an additional means in an additional place.

Item 17 inserts a new section 14A, which together with item 16 provides for a more prescriptive and extensive publication regime for special management orders so that rather than leave it to the court's discretion, the Minister will be obliged to publish in two national newspapers and he or she may publish by an additional means in an additional place. In addition, where a relevant institution has its shares traded on a financial market, upon being served with the order by the Minister, it will be required to announce the existence of the order to a regulatory news service and to provide it with a copy of the order. The intention here is to provide for the widest possible dissemination of the existence of the order among the people who might be affected by it.

Item 18 amends section 16(1) to increase the time in which an application to set aside special management orders may be brought from five working days after the making of a special management order to 14 days after the publication of a special management order. The effect of this will be to give applicants more time to consider their position. This extension of the period in which set-aside can be sought is consequential upon the decision to provide that orders can have immediate effect to balance competing rights.

Item 19 amends section 16(2) to provide clarity with regard to the court's power to make directions as to matters arising during the currency of an application to set aside a special management order.
Item 20 amends section 16 to provide clarity as to the effectiveness of a special management order where an application to set aside the order is unsuccessful.

The amendment also provides that in an application to set aside a special management order, where the applicant is a member of the relevant institution, the court will be permitted to take into consideration when an applicant became a member, when he or she increased or decreased his or her shareholding in the institution concerned, and the value of any shares acquired or disposed on the dates of acquisition or disposal. This amendment is proposed in response to the Department's practical experience in applying for orders under the CIS Act since its commencement in December 2010. However, it will certainly involve some consolidation and perhaps ideas such as a central credit union providing IT facilities or the risk management function on a hub and spoke basis. None of this is finalised but it is only fair to give the committee a flavour of the thinking before we move to the next stage. I expect to have the credit union report in the coming weeks and I will take it to the Government. We will publish it and ensure it is available to everybody. We will have to legislate between now and Christmas. This is a priority at this stage. It was next in line after the banks being reorganised and recapitalised and the next issue in the financial services area is the credit union movement. It is also the last issue we must deal with and proportionately, it is not as big an issue as the banks, although it is very significant. It involves many of our communities and many decent people voluntarily give of their time to provide this service for their communities and neighbours. It is very important and we should proceed on that basis. That is the best I can do today.

We can reach agreement on amendment No. 100. I have been getting messages from individuals and representatives of the credit union movement throughout this meeting and they have discussed the amendment. They are very alarmed at the changes to the original 1997 Act. There has been no consultation, as the Minister has admitted. In addition, the commission has not discussed in any form any of the proposals before us and it is not even on the agenda. The representatives from the credit unions chair the commission.

This has come out of the blue and I agree that there is concern within that sector as to what will happen with consolidation. There is a need for resolution in some areas, which may be minor, while the rest of the credit union sector is quite healthy, with plenty of capital and much lending capacity for the domestic economy.

The Minister has indicated his representatives will meet with the commission tomorrow, which is welcome, and that his intention is to meet representatives of the credit union sector, including the Irish League of Credit Unions.

Tomorrow the commission has a meeting and I will raise the issue through my officials, asking for the advice of the commission on it. This is technical in nature so the officials will brief the Irish League of Credit Unions.
That is fine.
The officials will report to me. I will not be able to meet them personally tomorrow.

I do not expect the Minister to meet them personally. Will the Minister instruct his officials to go to the meeting not just to brief the attendees but also to listen to any sensible amendments that could be considered for the legislation on Report Stage?

Yes, but the Deputy should remember the context. The Central Bank and the regulator are the regulatory authorities for the credit union. They have requested these powers; we did not invent them. The Central Bank considers that it needs the power because it has done in-depth stress testing of the credit unions around the country and it needs resolution powers to resolve any issues.

There will be resolution powers but the sector may have a sensible view that we could all agree on. For example, one of the issues affecting many communities now is the limit placed on some credit unions, particularly with regard to lending capacity. Setting a €10,000 limit to an individual who is well able to repay a loan makes no sense. Limits are being imposed on credit unions and in some cases I remain to be convinced that they make sense. A credit union is a different animal from a normal bank. I accept the Minister's comments and on that basis I would be happy to let the amendment go.
I welcome the Minister's comments. Does this section apply to day-to-day involvement of the regulator with the credit unions? Is it very much in the vein of a resolution?
These are the pre-conditions before the Central Bank can move towards a resolution.

A Department of Finance official is a member of the commission that is meeting tomorrow. The commission will be briefed and have the opportunity to give its views before the official returns to the Minister. There will be dialogue with the Irish League of Credit Unions and the Credit Union Development Association, and the Minister may be open to consideration on Report Stage with regard to particular sections.
There is nothing outrageous in the list of provisions that I can see.
There is an obvious need for dialogue, which will happen in the next couple of days.

These are the pre-conditions. There is a requirement that a credit union would raise, within such a period as may be specified, and maintain, such capital reserves or other financial resources, or to maintain such non-financial resources as may be specified. That seems reasonable to me if we were to approach a credit union might be getting into difficulty. It is built on the existing power of the Central Bank to issue a direction to a financial institution.

The concern exists that with bodies which are essentially voluntary in nature, Mr. Elderfield and the Governor of the Central Bank are regarding them as if they are fully professional financial institutions. For example, Deputy Doherty made a point about the amount of credit, etc., and there is also the issue of audit committees, how they work and the amount of professional guidance now required at a significant cost. These are areas which should be considered. It is almost as if we take a junior rugby club in the Minister's city and apply to it the same kind of terms and conditions as may be applied to the Munster team. It is of a different order.
Has the Deputy seen our junior clubs?

The order has changed. I remember when credit unions were in the back of the parish hall on a Wednesday and Friday night, with some well meaning lady behind the table with a book sorting things out. The Deputy should go down the country now to visit some of the credit union offices.
Most people are members.
We welcome the dialogue.

They are dealing with significant amounts of money. Some of the larger credit unions are handling an enormous amount of money. We must be very prudent about this as I remember all the information we got before the banks crashed. There was no bank in Ireland in trouble and everything was grand. We were asked why we were getting upset as the Irish banking system was different from that of America.
It was a new model.
We welcome the dialogue.
We have made considerable progress on that and I suggest we move on.

Substitute:“(5) If the Court sets aside a transfer order, no further assets or liabilities shall be transferred as a consequence of the transfer order.(6) The setting aside of a transfer order does not affect the rights of a transferee or the transferee’s title to any asset or liability so transferred before that setting-aside.(7) If a transfer order is set aside and assets or liabilities have been transferred pursuant to it, the transferor is not entitled to any payment other than the consideration paid pursuant to the transfer order.(8) If a variation or amendment of a transfer order made under this section would, but for this subsection, have the effect of setting aside a disposition of an asset or liability, subsections (5) to (7) apply with any necessary modifications.(9) The Court, in considering the order it wishes to make under this section, may, where the applicant is a member of a relevant institution, have regard to—(a) the date on which the applicant became a member of that institution, or increased or decreased the number of shares that the applicant held in that institution, and(b) the value of the shares acquired by or disposed of by the member as at the date or dates on which the shares were acquired or disposed of, as the case may be.”.

For “financial collateral arrangement (within the meaning of the European Communities (Financial Collateral Arrangements) Regulations 2004 (S.I. No. 1 of 2004))”, substitute “financial collateral arrangement (within the meaning of Directive 2002/47/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 6 June 20021 on financial collateral arrangements, as amended by Directive 2009/44/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 6 May 20092, and of the European Communities (Financial Collateral Arrangements) Regulations 2010 (S.I. No 626 of 2010))”.
Delete “entitled and subject to if” and substitute “entitled and subject if”.

After subsection (5), insert:“(5A) If—(a) the transferor is a credit union or a building society,(b) a share account is included in the transfer of assets and liabilities, and(c) the share account becomes a deposit account in the transferee pursuant to subsection (5),the holder of that account continues to have the membership rights in the transferor that he or she had before the transfer, including (without limitation) voting rights and rights to participate in any surplus on a winding-up.(5B) Subsection (5A) has effect notwithstanding anything in—(a) the Building Societies Act 1989 or the Credit Union Act 1997, or(b) the memorandum of association or rules of the transferor.”.

Substitute:“(6) The transfer of assets and liabilities under a transfer order takes effect notwithstanding—(a) any duty or obligation to any person that would otherwise prevent or restrict the transfer,(b) any provision of any enactment, rule of law, code of practice or agreement providing for or requiring—(i) notice to any person,(ii) the consent, approval or concurrence of any person, or(iii) any formality such as registration,(c) any other rule of law or equity,(d) any code of practice made under an enactment,(e) the listing rules of a regulated market or the rules of any other market on which the shares of the transferor are traded,(f) the memorandum of association or articles of association of the transferor, or(g) any agreement which the transferor is a party to, is bound by, or has an interest in,except to any extent to which the transfer order expressly provides otherwise.”.

After subsection (2), insert:“(2A) If the Minister imposes a requirement on a relevant institution and the intention of it or part of it is the preservation or restoration of the financial position of a credit institution, the Minister shall declare in the requirement that the requirement or part is made with that intention, in accordance with the CIWUD Directive.”.
Insert “or requirement imposed under section 50” after “Act”.

After section 52, insert the following:“Costs incurred in relation to making orders, etc.52A.— Where the Courts Service, or another body funded, wholly or partly, out of moneys provided by the Oireachtas, or from the Central Fund or the growing produce of the Central Fund, has incurred costs in relation to the translation or publication of an order under this Act (including where the translation or publication is required by the European Communities (Reorganisation and Winding-Up of Credit Institutions) Regulations 2011 (S.I. No. 48 of 2011)), the costs are a debt due and owing by the credit institution concerned, and may be recovered as a simple contract debt in any court of competent jurisdiction.”.
Insert “(other than the Minister)” after “person shall not”.
Insert “(whether or not the order or requirement is subsequently set aside, or varied or amended in a relevant manner)” after “subsidiary of its holding company”.
